holdings.text: Article 178 of the Limitation Act applies to applications made by the parties and not to the filing of the award by the arbitrators.

anchor.surface_text: Article 178 of the Limitation Act which was relied upon by the appellant applies to applications made by the parties and not to the filing of the award by the arbitrators.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitrators filed award within time; limitation provision distinguished as applying only to party applications under s.14(2).

holdings.text: The filing of an unregistered award under s.49 of the Registration Act is not prohibited; what is prohibited is that it cannot be taken into evidence so as to affect immovable property falling under s.17.

anchor.surface_text: The filing of an unregistered award under s. 49 of the Registration Act is not prohibited what is prohibited is that it cannot be taken into evidence so as to affect immoveable property falling under s. 17 of that Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory prohibition limited to evidentiary use affecting property, not filing; registration later validated.

holdings.text: Lists of property were not necessary for registration in the circumstances, and Mithulal's actions do not affect legality.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has found that in the circumstances of this case lists were not necessary and therefore anything done by Mithulal whether authorised or not will not affect the legality of the registration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court factual finding on s.21/22 requirements accepted; procedural defect immaterial.

holdings.text: The First Additional District Judge had jurisdiction to extend time for the award as proceedings under s.192 Succession Act were pending before it.

anchor.surface_text: the court which had jurisdiction to entertain applications for the filing of awards was the same before whom the application under s. 192 of the Succession Act had been filed. If that court was the proper court...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court seized of related proceedings has jurisdiction to extend arbitrators' time.

holdings.text: No misconduct by arbitrators proved; charge based on after-thought, explained as amicable settlement attempt, no inference from evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has found that this charge has not been proved... There is nothing wrong in what the arbitrators did and it cannot be said that any inference of misconduct can be drawn from this evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence insufficient; not pleaded initially, contextualized as settlement effort.

holdings.text: Award not in excess of arbitrators' powers; within scope of agreement to decide rights on adoption/non-adoption, time limit implicit.

anchor.surface_text: It was then submitted that the award was in excess of the powers given to the arbitrators... The arbitrators decided that the respondent should adopt the appellant according to Hindu Law within four months...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement empowered decision on adoption consequences; maintained will gifts; no showing of excess or contrariety to law.

holdings.text: According to true construction of will, appellant not constituted executor eo nomine until adoption by testator or widow.

anchor.surface_text: according to the true construction of the will the appellant was not to become the executor till he had been adopted... the appellant was not constituted an executor eo nomine but was to be an executor if he was adopted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Para 10 of will conditional on adoption; renders executor argument inapplicable.

holdings.text: Appellant refused adoption, as found on evidence; courts correctly applied award consequences.

anchor.surface_text: the courts below have found on the evidence that the appellant was not prepared to be adopted. We have been taken through the evidence and we find no reason to differ...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence review concurs with lower courts; appellant's own appeal grounds confirm refusal.

holdings.text: Question of reference validity unnecessary to decide, as appellant not executor.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to decide the validity of this point because according to the true construction of the will the appellant was not to become the executor till he had been adopted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue moot due to will construction.

holdings.text: Question of discharge under s.301 Succession Act does not arise, as appellant not constituted executor.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly the question whether the appellant after accepting the office of an executor had renounced it or a discharge was necessary under s. 301 of the Succession Act does not arise.
